case_vignette: A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician because of an increasingly painful swelling behind her right knee for the past 2 months. During this time, she has also had intermittent low-grade fever and she has been more fatigued than usual. She has not had any trauma to the knee. Over the past year, she has had occasional pain in her hands and wrists bilaterally. She has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She drinks 1–2 glasses of wine daily and occasionally more on weekends. Current medications include enalapril, metformin, and glimepiride. Her mother and older brother have osteoarthritis. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 68 kg (150 lb); BMI is 25 kg/m2. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a 3-cm nontender mass in the right popliteal fossa that becomes prominent when the knee is extended. There is mild swelling and redness of her right knee joint.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

trial_2.summarized_mcq: Based on the given symptoms, the most likely diagnosis is Popliteal artery aneurysm. Gout typically presents with sudden, severe pain, redness, and swelling in a joint, often the big toe. Rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus usually present with a combination of joint pain and swelling, fatigue, and other systemic symptoms, but they do not typically cause pain and swelling behind the knee without joint involvement. Popliteal artery aneurysms can cause pain, swelling, and fever due to inflammation and infection of the surrounding tissue.
trial_2.summarized_frq: Based on the given symptoms, the most likely diagnosis is inflammatory arthritis, specifically, it could be Oligoarticular Gout or Psoriatic Arthritis. However, without further investigation, it is essential to consider other possibilities, and a definitive diagnosis should be made by a healthcare professional. It is important to note that this response should not be used as a substitute for professional medical advice.
